alt_statements.statement: As someone who has spent a career in public education and community work, I believe policing should be grounded in transparency, rigorous de-escalation training, and meaningful accountability for misconduct, including independent oversight of use-of-force incidents. We need to invest in bias training that’s continuous and evidence-based, shift appropriate calls (like mental health crises) to specialized responders, and build partnerships between police, schools, and community organizations so safety is achieved through trust and prevention rather than fear and intimidation.

As a journalist and a liberal Catholic, I believe policing must be rooted in both accountability and human dignity: that means rigorous bias training tied to measurable outcomes, body cameras with real transparency, and independent review boards that have actual power. At the same time, we need to invest in data-driven approaches—like using technology and community-based alternatives for mental health and substance calls—so officers are reserved for situations that truly require a law-enforcement response, reducing unnecessary use of force while keeping the public safe.

As someone who loves this country’s land and people and believes in caring for “the least of these,” I think policing needs stricter, transparent standards on use of force and real accountability when officers cross the line, because authority without responsibility just breeds mistrust. We ought to invest heavily in de-escalation training, mental health responders, and community-based programs so that officers aren’t the first or only tool we reach for, especially in marginalized neighborhoods. At the same time, communities deserve to feel safe, so we should focus police resources on serious crimes and build genuine relationships between officers and residents, instead of treating folks like suspects by default.

Police have a tough job, and we still need them to keep order and protect people, but that doesn’t mean they should get a blank check on force. I think we need better training that focuses on de-escalation and clear, consistent rules for when force is allowed, plus body cameras and independent reviews when things go wrong so everyone knows the process is fair. At the same time, we shouldn’t tie officers’ hands so much that they’re afraid to step in when crime is happening; good cops need backup from the system, and bad cops need to be held personally accountable.

As someone who cares about both community safety and fairness, I think police departments need stronger de-escalation training, clear limits on use of force, and real accountability when officers cross the line—including independent investigations. Bias training alone isn’t enough; we need better screening and ongoing evaluations to keep people with aggressive or prejudiced tendencies off the force in the first place. At the same time, I want officers supported with good pay, mental health resources, and staffing levels so they’re not constantly operating on adrenaline and burnout. Public safety and civil rights aren’t competing goals—if people don’t trust the police, they’re less likely to cooperate, and that makes everyone less safe.

Como madre y vecina en una comunidad latina, creo que la policía debe enfocarse en la desescalación, el entrenamiento contra prejuicios raciales y el trabajo cercano con la comunidad para reducir el uso excesivo de la fuerza. Mantener la seguridad pública es importante, pero no a costa de que nuestros hijos y vecinos vivan con miedo; como dice Elena Poniatowska, “no se puede vivir sin esperanza”, y esa esperanza incluye confiar en que la ley nos protege a todos por igual.

As someone who cares about my community and reads a lot about justice and history, I think policing needs to be re-centered on fairness, accountability, and respect for human dignity, especially for people of color like many in my neighborhood. Strategies like better bias training, using body cameras, having independent investigations of use-of-force, and sending mental health or social workers to certain calls can all help reduce harm while keeping us safe. I also believe investing in schools, youth programs, and community resources is just as important as any policing reform, because real public safety comes from people having opportunities and feeling valued, not just from more patrol cars.

As someone who believes in law and order but also fairness, I think policing should focus on rigorous training, clear rules of engagement, and strict accountability so that officers use force only when truly necessary. We should support our police with better screening, ongoing bias and de-escalation training, body cameras, and strong leadership, while also backing them to act decisively to protect the public. I don’t think the answer is to “defund” the police, but to reform and professionalize the force so that communities—especially families like mine—can trust that the law is applied consistently and respectfully.

As someone who believes strongly in law and order but also in basic fairness, I think our police need both firm support and clear standards that prevent bias and unnecessary violence. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and community relations, hold officers accountable when they clearly misuse force, and also make sure they have the resources and staffing they need to do a very difficult job. Transparent reporting on use-of-force incidents and body camera footage can help maintain public trust, while still allowing officers to act decisively to protect the public.

As someone who works in our public schools and is raising young kids in this community, I want policing that treats every person fairly and with dignity while still keeping us safe. We should prioritize de‑escalation training, mental health responders, and strong accountability measures—like body cameras and transparent investigations—so that bias and excessive force are addressed head‑on. Investing in youth programs, education, and community outreach can prevent problems before they start and build real trust between officers and the neighborhoods they serve.

I believe most police officers are good people doing a difficult job, and we still need strong law enforcement to keep our communities safe. At the same time, I support better training in de-escalation, mental health, and bias awareness, along with body cameras and clear rules on use of force so officers are held accountable when they cross the line. We don’t need to “defund” the police, but we do need higher standards and consistent oversight so both citizens and officers can feel protected and respected.

Growing up Apache and seeing how our people and other communities of color are treated, I think police need to be trained to really understand our history, our culture, and the trauma that comes from generations of distrust. They should be held strictly accountable for excessive force, wear body cameras, and have independent investigations when someone is hurt or killed. At the same time, more resources should go into community-based approaches and mental health support so police don’t answer every problem with force. Public safety should mean protecting everyone with respect and fairness, not making certain groups feel afraid.

I think police should try really hard to be fair to everyone and not treat people badly because of what they look like or where they’re from. They should talk and listen more before using force, and only use it if someone is really in danger. I feel safer when I know they protect us but also respect people in my neighborhood, so kids like me can play outside without being scared.

As a Yaqui woman, a mother, and someone who believes deeply in social justice, I think policing needs to be reimagined with stronger community relationships at its core—officers should know the people they serve, not just patrol them. We need mandatory de-escalation and anti-bias training with real accountability when force is misused, alongside investments in mental health and social services so police aren’t the default response to every crisis. True public safety should look more like a well-tended neighborhood mural—many hands contributing, everyone respected, and no one erased or brutalized in the name of “order.”

As a retired teacher, I’ve seen how trust and respect can change behavior far more effectively than fear, and I think the same is true for policing. We need strong, consistent training on de-escalation and implicit bias, firm accountability for misconduct, and independent investigations of serious use-of-force incidents, especially in communities of color. At the same time, we should invest in community policing, mental health responders, and youth programs so officers are partners with the neighborhoods they serve, not just enforcers. That kind of balanced approach protects public safety while upholding the dignity and rights of everyone.

As a Black man, a dad, and someone who works hard every day to support my family, I want policing that truly protects us without treating us like suspects first. We need strong accountability—body cameras, transparent investigations, and real consequences for misuse of force—combined with better training on de-escalation and implicit bias. At the same time, officers should be supported with the resources and community partnerships they need to handle tough situations safely. When police know our names, show up at our community events, and work with us instead of against us, it makes everyone safer.

I think most cops are trying to do a hard job and keep people safe, but there should still be clear rules, good training, and body cameras to keep everyone honest and reduce bias and unnecessary force. We need to back the police so they’re not afraid to step in when crime happens, but if someone abuses their power, they should be held accountable just like anyone else.

As someone who’s lived a long life watching this country change, I believe we need policing that is both firm about public safety and honest about the bias and excessive force that have damaged trust, especially in communities of color. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and implicit bias, stronger accountability and transparent oversight when force is used, and alternative responses for mental health and nonviolent calls so officers aren’t forced into roles they’re not suited for. That kind of balanced approach respects people’s rights and dignity while still keeping our neighborhoods safe.

As someone who believes in law and order but also in basic fairness, I think policing needs stricter standards, better training in de-escalation, and real accountability when officers abuse their power. We should support good cops with the tools and staffing they need to keep communities safe, while using body cameras, transparent investigations, and bias training to make sure everyone—no matter their background—is treated with respect.

I think police should be trained really well to stay calm and fair with everyone, no matter what they look like or where they’re from, because it’s scary when people feel like they can’t trust them. They should have cameras on, clear rules about when they can use force, and get in trouble if they break those rules. I also think they should spend more time getting to know the kids and families in their neighborhoods so people feel safe asking them for help instead of being afraid.

I think cops need way better training on bias and de-escalation so they don’t jump straight to force, especially with Black people and other minorities who get treated harsher for no reason. There should be clear rules, body cams on all the time, and real consequences when an officer abuses their power so communities can actually trust them. At the same time, we still need police to deal with serious crime, but they should work with neighborhoods, not act like they’re at war with them.

As a conservative and someone who values law and order, I believe we need to support our police while also insisting on high professional standards, better training in de-escalation, and clear consequences for genuine misconduct. Bias and excessive force should be addressed with solid data, body cameras, and consistent policies, not political grandstanding or “defund the police” slogans that make communities less safe. I’d like to see departments invest more in community-based policing, where officers actually know the neighborhoods they serve, so trust is built on real relationships rather than stereotypes.

Como alguien que creció aquí y ve las noticias de casos de brutalidad, creo que la policía sí es necesaria para la seguridad pública, pero tiene que cambiar la forma en que trabaja, especialmente en vecindarios latinos. Deberían recibir entrenamiento fuerte y continuo contra el racismo y el uso excesivo de fuerza, usar más desescalación, cámaras corporales y transparencia, y trabajar en equipo con la comunidad, no contra ella. También quiero que haya consecuencias claras cuando un oficial abusa de su poder, porque sin rendición de cuentas no hay confianza. Si la gente confía en la policía, es más fácil prevenir el crimen y mantener a todos seguros.

As a lawyer and a Christian, I believe we have a moral and constitutional obligation to reform policing so that bias and excessive force are not tolerated, while still ensuring that officers can protect communities effectively. That means stronger accountability measures—like independent review of serious incidents, better data collection, and firm consequences for misconduct—paired with rigorous training in de-escalation, implicit bias, and mental health crisis response. We should also invest in community-based services and alternative responders for nonviolent situations so police are not asked to be social workers, medics, and counselors all at once. Done right, these reforms can rebuild public trust and make both citizens and officers safer.

As someone who cares about justice and grew up around a lot of different kinds of people in New York, I think policing has to be rooted in accountability and transparency if it’s ever going to earn real trust. We need strong, enforced policies against biased stops and excessive force, mandatory body cams, and independent investigations when things go wrong, while shifting resources toward mental health responders and community-based programs that actually prevent crime. At the same time, officers should get serious, ongoing training in de-escalation and implicit bias so they can handle tense situations without reaching for a weapon first, because public safety and civil rights should never be treated like they’re in conflict.

Police officers have a tough job, and we need them to keep our communities safe, but that doesn’t mean they shouldn’t be held to clear standards. I believe in strong training on de-escalation and fair treatment for everyone, along with body cameras and firm consequences when officers abuse their power. At the same time, we should respect and support good officers who follow the rules, because without law and order, none of us are truly safe.

Police have a tough job, and we need them to keep our communities safe, but that doesn’t mean we should ignore real concerns about bias and excessive force. I think the answer is better training in de-escalation, stricter standards for when force can be used, and body cameras for transparency—paired with strong support for good officers who follow the rules. We should use technology and data to track patterns of misconduct and address problems early, instead of waiting for a tragedy. This way we can hold bad actors accountable without undermining the overall authority and morale of the police.

As a physician working in a hospital where I see the physical and psychological consequences of excessive force, I believe policing strategies must prioritize de-escalation, rigorous bias training, and strong accountability mechanisms, including independent review of use-of-force incidents. At the same time, officers need sufficient support, training, and resources to safely manage genuinely dangerous situations, because public safety and civil rights are not opposing goals. Community-based policing—where officers know the people they serve, engage transparently, and build trust—can reduce both bias and violence, ultimately creating safer neighborhoods for everyone.

I think police should be trained to treat everyone fairly, no matter their race or neighborhood, and there should be real consequences when officers use too much force. They should get to know the community, like talking with kids and families at schools and parks, so people see them as helpers instead of something to be scared of. I believe we can have both safety and respect if officers learn to de‑escalate situations first and listen more before reaching for a weapon.

I think police should treat everyone fairly and kindly, like how my coaches treat all players on my soccer team, no matter what they look like. They should get really good training on not judging people by their race and on using force only when they absolutely have to, and cameras should be used so everyone can see what really happened. If people can trust that officers are trying to protect them and not hurt them for no reason, then neighborhoods will feel safer and kids like me won’t be scared when we see a police car.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how trauma affects communication, behavior, and long-term wellbeing, I believe policing needs to be fundamentally grounded in de-escalation, bias training, and community-based models that prioritize preserving life. We should invest heavily in alternatives to armed response—like mental health crisis teams and social workers—while holding officers clearly accountable for excessive force and discriminatory practices. True public safety comes from trust and prevention, not fear, so policies must be transparent, data-driven, and shaped in partnership with the communities most impacted by policing.

As a mom, a teacher, and a progressive, I want my kids and my students to grow up in communities where they can trust the police and also feel truly safe. That means investing in de-escalation and anti-bias training, putting real accountability measures in place (like body cameras and independent review boards), and shifting many mental health and social service calls to trained professionals instead of armed officers. At the same time, we should build stronger community policing that is rooted in relationships and problem-solving, so officers know the neighborhoods they serve and work with residents rather than just policing them.

As someone who values personal responsibility and individual rights, I think policing needs stronger accountability measures and better training in de-escalation and bias awareness, so everyone is treated fairly regardless of who they are. At the same time, I want officers to feel supported in doing a tough job, with clear rules and body cameras to protect both the public and the police. We don’t have to choose between safety and justice—we need policies and leadership that insist on both.

As someone who supports law enforcement and believes in personal responsibility, I think we need strong, well-funded police departments, but also clear standards and accountability so bad actors are removed from the job. Training should focus heavily on de-escalation, treating everyone with respect, and recognizing bias, while still allowing officers to use appropriate force when lives are on the line. Community policing and more face-to-face interaction can build trust so officers are seen as partners, not enemies. We don’t fix problems by weakening the police, but by improving how they operate and making sure the good cops are backed and the bad ones are dealt with swiftly.

As a teacher and a Catholic, I believe policing must be grounded in the same principles I try to model in my classroom: dignity, fairness, and accountability. We should invest in rigorous bias training, de-escalation tactics, mental health partnerships, and meaningful community oversight so that officers are equipped and required to use force only as a last resort. At the same time, we need to support good officers with proper resources and clear standards so they can keep communities safe without communities—especially communities of color—feeling targeted or afraid.

At my age, I’ve seen enough to know that real public safety depends on trust, and you don’t build trust when certain communities live in fear of the very people sworn to protect them. We need stricter national standards on use of force, independent investigations of misconduct, and ongoing anti-bias training rooted in actual community experience, not just PowerPoint slides. At the same time, officers deserve proper support, clear rules, and the expectation that de-escalation is the default whenever possible. If we invest in mental health services, community programs, and accountable policing together, we can reduce both crime and unnecessary violence.

As someone who cares deeply about the safety and well-being of my community, I believe we need strong, well-funded police departments that are also held to clear, consistent standards. I support more rigorous training in de-escalation, implicit bias, and mental health response, along with body cameras and transparent review of serious use-of-force incidents. At the same time, officers deserve fair treatment, proper resources, and the benefit of the doubt when they follow the rules and put their lives on the line. The goal should be to build trust, not tear down law enforcement, so that all law-abiding citizens feel protected and respected.

As a Black Christian man and a counselor who’s spent his life listening to people’s stories, I believe effective policing must start with building trust through transparency, accountability, and genuine community partnership. We need strong, enforceable standards on use of force, robust bias and de-escalation training, and clear consequences when officers abuse their power—because public safety can’t exist without public confidence. At the same time, investing in mental health services, youth programs, and social supports will reduce the situations that lead to confrontations in the first place, allowing police to focus on the cases that truly require an armed response.

As someone who cares a lot about fairness and protecting people and the environment, I think police should get strong training on de-escalation, recognizing their own biases, and how to build real trust with the communities they serve. There should be clear rules and accountability when officers use force, with body cameras and independent investigations, so people feel safe reporting problems. At the same time, police should work closely with schools, social workers, and local groups to prevent violence before it happens, instead of just reacting to it. That way we can have both safety and justice, without certain groups feeling targeted or afraid.

I think police should have strict rules and constant training so they don’t judge people by race or how they look, because that just makes communities scared instead of safe. There should be body cameras, clear consequences when officers use force unfairly, and more officers who actually know and talk to the people in our neighborhoods. If police worked with local churches, schools, and youth groups, they could prevent problems before they turn violent. Protecting people’s rights and treating everyone with respect is part of real public safety, not something separate from it.

As a progressive school administrator, I see bias and use-of-force issues in policing much like I see discipline in schools: if you don’t address root causes, train for de-escalation, and demand real accountability, you’re just managing crises instead of preventing them. We need evidence-based reforms—implicit bias and de-escalation training tied to measurable outcomes, independent oversight of misconduct, and clear limits on lethal force—so that officers are truly guardians, not warriors. At the same time, investing in mental health services, community-based violence prevention, and youth programs will reduce the situations where police force is even on the table, strengthening public safety in a way that aligns with both justice and common sense.

As a teacher and a Democrat who cares deeply about my students’ safety and futures, I believe policing needs strong accountability measures—like body cameras, transparent use-of-force reviews, and meaningful consequences for misconduct—to address racial bias and rebuild trust. At the same time, we should shift resources toward mental health services, community-based programs, and de-escalation training so officers are not the default response to every problem but partners in keeping our neighborhoods safe and fair for everyone.

As someone who cares a lot about family and safety, I believe we need police who are both strongly committed to protecting communities and clearly held accountable when force is misused or bias plays a role. That means better training in de-escalation and cultural awareness, consistent consequences for misconduct, and more community-focused policing so officers actually know the people they serve. We don’t need to “defund” the police, but we do need to reform policies and data reporting so that force is truly a last resort and everyone, especially people of color, can trust that they’ll be treated fairly.

As someone who has lived a quiet, disciplined life and believes deeply in non-harm, I think policing must prioritize de-escalation, empathy, and strict accountability for misconduct, especially in cases of bias and excessive force. Officers should receive continuous training in cultural competence and mental health crisis response, and independent civilian oversight should review serious incidents. At the same time, public safety can be protected by investing in community-based services—such as social workers, mental health professionals, and violence prevention programs—so that police are not the default responders to every problem. True safety comes from trust and fairness, not fear.

As a healthcare professional who works closely with people in pain and vulnerability, I believe policing must prioritize de-escalation, implicit-bias training, and strict accountability for excessive force, while still ensuring officers have the support and resources needed to respond effectively to real threats. We should invest heavily in community-based programs, mental health responders, and youth services alongside evidence-based reforms to use-of-force policies, so public safety is built on trust, fairness, and respect for human dignity rather than fear.

As someone who’s worn a uniform and believes deeply in law and order, I think we need to support our police while holding them to the highest professional standards. We should focus on better training in de-escalation, clear and consistent use-of-force rules, and body cameras to protect both officers and citizens. Any deliberate bias or abuse of authority should be dealt with quickly and firmly, but we shouldn’t hamstring officers with political agendas that make it harder for them to keep our communities safe. Public safety depends on strong, well-led police departments that have both the tools and the backing to do their jobs right.

As a mom raising young kids, I want them to grow up in a community where they can trust the police and where everyone is treated fairly, regardless of race or background. We need stronger de-escalation training, real accountability for misuse of force, and independent oversight so that officers who abuse their power are removed, while those who serve with integrity are supported. At the same time, investing in mental health services, youth programs, and community-based solutions can reduce the need for force in the first place and make neighborhoods safer for everyone.

My mom and dad tell me that police are supposed to keep us safe and help people, and I want everyone to feel safe, no matter what they look like. I think police should be kind and careful, use their words first, and only hurt people if they really have to so no one gets scared or feels treated unfairly.

I believe most police officers are good people doing a tough job, and they deserve strong support, but that doesn’t mean we should ignore bad actors or bias when it shows up. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and unconscious bias, hold officers clearly accountable when they cross the line, and make sure policies are applied fairly to everyone. At the same time, we must not weaken law enforcement so much that criminals feel emboldened and our communities become less safe. The goal should be a system where police are trusted protectors, not feared, and where law-abiding citizens—no matter who they are—feel both respected and secure.

My mom and dad tell me that police should be helpers who keep everyone safe, no matter what they look like. Grown-ups should teach police to be gentle first, listen carefully, and only use force when they really have to. I feel safer when people in charge are kind and fair and don’t hurt people just because they’re different.

I think police should be really kind and careful with people, and try talking and listening first instead of hurting anyone. My parents say everyone should be treated fairly no matter what they look like, because God loves all of us the same. I feel safer when I see grown-ups solving problems with calm voices and helping each other instead of fighting.

As a husband, dad, and warehouse worker who believes in both public safety and disability rights, I think policing needs more rigorous de-escalation training, strong accountability for excessive force, and real consequences when bias shows up in stops and arrests. We should invest in community-based approaches—like mental health crisis teams and youth programs—so cops aren’t the default for every problem and so people with disabilities and people of color are safer in encounters with law enforcement. At the same time, officers should have the support, training, and staffing they need to do their jobs well, because my family and coworkers still rely on them to respond quickly when there’s real danger.

As someone who’s lived a long life in this country as a Black woman from Texas, I’ve seen how policing can feel very different depending on the color of your skin and the neighborhood you’re in. We need stronger accountability measures, better training in de-escalation and implicit bias, and a real shift in culture so officers see themselves as guardians, not warriors. At the same time, communities deserve to feel safe, so we should invest in mental health services, education, and community programs that reduce crime before it starts, rather than relying on force after the fact. If the police worked more closely with the people they serve, listening instead of just ordering, we’d all be better off and a lot safer.

Mi mami y papi dicen que los policías deben cuidar a todos por igual y no pegarle fuerte a la gente solo por cómo se ve. Yo quiero que cuando crezca pueda confiar en los policías y que ellos sean amables y tranquilos, para que nadie tenga miedo y todos estemos seguros en el parque y en la calle.

As someone who’s lived a long life watching my community change, I believe we desperately need policing that emphasizes de-escalation, mental health support, and strong bias training so encounters don’t turn violent—especially for Black and brown neighbors who’ve borne the brunt of unfair treatment. We can maintain public safety by shifting resources toward community-based programs, better officer screening and accountability, and independent review of use-of-force, so the police are seen as partners instead of threats.

As someone who believes in both personal responsibility and the importance of public safety, I think we need policing that is firm but fair, grounded in clear standards and real accountability. Departments should invest in rigorous, ongoing training on de-escalation, bias awareness, and mental health, with body cameras and transparent reporting so the public can see that use of force is truly a last resort. At the same time, we have to make sure officers have the tools, staffing, and community support they need to respond quickly to crime and protect families like mine. Balanced, data-driven policies—not political extremes—are the best way to rebuild trust and keep neighborhoods safe.

As a young mom raising kids in this community, I want police who keep our neighborhoods safe but also treat every person with dignity and fairness. I think officers need better training on de-escalation and recognizing their own biases, along with body cameras and real accountability when force is misused. At the same time, we should invest in things that prevent crime in the first place—like youth programs, mental health support, and strong family services—so officers aren’t always the only ones responding to tough situations. That balance respects the value of every life, which for me is rooted in both my faith and my belief in protecting families.

I think police should get more training on how to stay calm and treat everyone fairly, no matter what they look like or where they’re from. They should use force only when they absolutely have to, and there should be cameras and clear rules so people can see when they do something wrong. At the same time, we still need police to keep us safe, so I’d like to see more officers getting to know kids and families in the community so we can trust each other more.

As someone who works with young children every day, I believe policing strategies should center on de-escalation, implicit bias training, and strong accountability so that kids grow up seeing law enforcement as protectors, not threats. We need community-based policing that truly partners with families and neighborhoods, transparent investigations of use-of-force incidents, and clear consequences when officers abuse their power. At the same time, adequately resourcing departments for training and mental health support can help officers make better decisions in high-stress situations, which ultimately keeps everyone safer.

As someone who believes in fairness and public safety, I think policing needs stronger accountability measures—like body cameras, independent oversight, and transparent investigations—so that officers who misuse force or act with bias are held responsible. At the same time, departments should invest in better training on de-escalation, mental health, and cultural awareness, and shift more resources toward community-based programs that prevent crime in the first place. I want to feel safe walking home from work at night, but I also want my community—especially people of color and marginalized groups—to be able to trust the police instead of fearing them.

I believe most police officers are good people trying to do a hard job, and we need to support them while still expecting fairness and restraint. Training should emphasize de-escalation, clear rules for when force is allowed, and treating everyone with respect, regardless of their background. At the same time, there should be real accountability when officers step over the line, so communities can trust that the law applies to everyone. If we balance strong, well-supported policing with common-sense oversight, we can keep our neighborhoods safe without tolerating abuse.

As someone who values law and order but also believes every person should be treated fairly, I think policing should focus on strong training, clear rules, and accountability without weakening officers’ ability to do their jobs. Officers need better de-escalation training and support so they can avoid unnecessary use of force, and departments should remove those who repeatedly abuse their authority. At the same time, we should respect and back the many good officers who protect our communities every day, because public safety and trust in the police have to go hand in hand.

As a retired businessman and lifelong Californian, I believe a community is safest when people can trust the police, not fear them. We need stronger bias training, real accountability for excessive force, and more officers walking the neighborhoods, talking to folks, and knowing them as people—especially in Hispanic and other minority communities. At the same time, we have to give good officers the resources, mental health support, and clear guidelines they need to do a tough job fairly and effectively. For me, faith and my love of tending a garden both teach the same lesson: if we want peace and safety to grow, we must pull out the roots of injustice while still protecting every life.

As someone who cares about both my community’s safety and fairness in how people are treated, I think policing needs stronger accountability, better training in de-escalation, and more transparency about use-of-force. We should invest in mental health responders and community programs so police aren’t the default for every problem, while still making sure officers have the support and clear rules they need to respond quickly to real threats.

I think police should focus way more on de-escalation and bias training so they don’t jump straight to force, especially against people of color, while still being there fast when someone is actually in danger. There should be body cams on all the time, real consequences when officers abuse their power, and more community-based programs so cops actually know the people they’re supposed to protect.

I think we need good cops and safe streets, but that has to go hand in hand with fair treatment for everyone, no matter their race or background. Departments should put more effort into training on de-escalation and bias, use body cameras consistently, and hold officers accountable when they cross the line. At the same time, we’ve got to support the many officers who do their jobs right with enough staffing, mental health support, and clear rules so they can respond quickly and decisively when there’s real danger.

As a young Black man from Texas who practices yoga and cares a lot about community and spirituality, I think policing has to start with seeing people’s humanity first. We need strong de-escalation training, strict accountability for biased or excessive use of force, and more investment in mental health and community-based responses so police aren’t the only tool we rely on. At the same time, I want my neighborhood to be safe, so I support well-trained officers who build real relationships with residents instead of treating us like suspects by default. That balance—firm accountability plus genuine community partnership—is how we protect both public safety and civil rights.

As a conservative, family-oriented high school teacher, I believe we need policing strategies that both hold officers accountable and allow them to do their jobs effectively. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and bias, ensure body cameras are consistently used and footage reviewed, and enforce clear consequences when officers violate policy. At the same time, we must support law enforcement with the resources, staffing, and public backing they need to keep communities—especially our kids—safe. Balancing firm accountability with strong support for good officers is the best way to reduce use-of-force incidents without sacrificing public safety.

As someone who has spent a lifetime teaching young people to think critically, and who came to this country from Haiti believing in its promises, I believe policing must be guided by transparency, accountability, and deep community partnership. We need strong national standards on use of force, mandatory body cameras, and independent civilian oversight, alongside serious investments in de-escalation training and implicit bias education. Protecting public safety and protecting civil rights are not opposing goals—officers who truly know, respect, and are answerable to the communities they serve are better able to keep everyone, including Black communities like mine, safe.

As a teacher and a Democrat, I believe policing should prioritize de-escalation, implicit bias training, and strong accountability measures so that use-of-force is truly a last resort. We need transparent data on stops, arrests, and force, along with independent oversight, to confront patterns of racial bias honestly. At the same time, investing in mental health services, social workers, and community programs can reduce the burden on police and address many issues before they become emergencies. Public safety is strongest when communities trust law enforcement and see them as partners, not threats.

As someone who believes deeply in both justice and community, I think policing must be guided by strict accountability, strong de-escalation training, and a clear commitment to treating every person with dignity, regardless of race or background. We can maintain public safety while dramatically reducing bias and excessive force by investing in community-based programs, mental health responders, and transparent oversight, so that officers are partners with the public rather than an occupying force.

As a Vietnamese American mother and caregiver, I want my children and the people I care for to feel safe around police, not afraid of them. Police departments should invest more in training that reduces bias and de‑escalates situations, and they should be held accountable when force is misused. At the same time, officers need support, clear rules, and enough staffing so they can respond calmly and fairly, especially in our most vulnerable communities. Focusing on community relationships, mental health resources, and social services alongside policing will protect both public safety and people’s dignity.

As a Hispanic guy who’s grown up seeing how policing can look really different depending on your neighborhood, I think we need serious reforms focused on accountability, bias training, and de-escalation so that everyone is treated fairly and humanely. I still want police to keep us safe, but that means investing in community-based programs, mental health responders, and body cameras and data transparency so force is a last resort, not a routine response.

As someone who has spent a lifetime believing in the power of education and community, I think policing must be guided by rigorous training on implicit bias, de-escalation, and mental health, with clear accountability when officers misuse force. We can and must maintain public safety, but that safety has to be mutual—officers protecting the public, and the public, especially people of color and vulnerable groups, feeling protected rather than targeted. I’d like to see more community-based policing where officers actually know the neighborhoods they serve, along with transparent data on stops and use-of-force so we can identify and correct patterns of bias.

As a retired paralegal and lifelong Michigander who cares deeply about both civil rights and safe neighborhoods, I believe policing must be guided by rigorous accountability: mandatory body cameras, transparent investigations of use-of-force, and real consequences for misconduct. At the same time, departments should invest in de-escalation training, anti-bias education grounded in data, and stronger partnerships with community organizations, so officers are seen as trusted partners rather than occupying forces. Modern technology—used responsibly—can help track patterns of stops and force, shining a light on bias and allowing departments to correct course before small problems become tragedies.

As someone who works long, hectic hours and just wants my friends and neighbors to get home safe, I think policing has to be both accountable and community-focused. We need strong, transparent rules around use of force, serious consequences for misconduct, and bias training that’s actually tied to hiring, promotion, and firing—not just a box to check. At the same time, a lot of what cops get called for (mental health crises, homelessness, addiction) should be handled by specialized community and social service teams so officers aren’t using force in situations that need care, not confrontation. If we care about the environment and public health, we should also be investing in safer, more stable communities—good jobs, housing, and services—so policing is a last resort, not the main tool for public safety.

As a young dad raising kids in a working-class neighborhood, I want them to grow up thinking the police are there to protect them, not scare them. We need stricter accountability and better training focused on de-escalation and recognizing bias, because too many people—especially from marginalized groups—are getting hurt when they shouldn’t. At the same time, we can’t just strip resources from public safety; we should invest in both good, community-focused policing and in mental health services, youth programs, and anti-poverty efforts that prevent crime in the first place.

As a young Chinese American mom raising my kid here, I want policing that protects us without making any community feel like a perpetual suspect. We need stronger bias and de-escalation training, strict accountability when officers use excessive force, and more unarmed responders for mental health or nonviolent calls, so police aren’t always the default. At the same time, I support well-trained officers having the resources they need to respond quickly and fairly to real threats, because safety and justice should go hand in hand.

My mom tells me that police should be fair to everyone and not hurt people just because of how they look, and I think that sounds right. I feel safer knowing they could help if something bad happens, but I want them to listen, be calm, and talk nicely so people aren’t scared.

As someone who’s seen a lot in 87 years, I believe we need strong, well-supported police to keep communities safe, but we also have to be honest that bias and excessive force hurt everyone’s trust in law and order. I think the answer is better training, stricter standards, and real accountability for officers who step out of line, without tying the hands of the many who do their jobs honorably.

As someone who believes strongly in law and order but also in basic human dignity, I think policing strategies need to combine firm enforcement with better training and accountability. Officers should receive more realistic de-escalation and bias training, wear body cameras, and know that clear misconduct will have real consequences, while also getting the resources and staffing they need to respond quickly and safely to crime. I don’t support “defunding” the police, but I do support reforms that improve transparency, strengthen community relationships, and ensure that everyone—no matter their background—is treated fairly and respectfully.

As a nurse who has spent her life caring for vulnerable people, I believe our police officers deserve strong support, good pay, and proper training, but that training must include clear standards on de-escalation, bias awareness, and accountability. We can back the blue and still insist that excessive force and unjust treatment are not tolerated, because every life has God-given dignity. I think practical steps—like body cameras, better screening and ongoing training, and closer cooperation between police and local communities and churches—can help reduce tragic incidents while keeping our neighborhoods safe.

As someone who values both justice and community safety, I believe policing needs strong accountability measures—like body cameras, independent investigations of use-of-force incidents, and real consequences for misconduct—to reduce bias and rebuild trust. Officers should receive intensive, ongoing training in de-escalation, mental health, and implicit bias, and departments must be transparent and engage regularly with the communities they serve. We can’t have real public safety if marginalized people are afraid of the police, so reforming policies, data collection, and oversight is essential to ensure everyone is treated fairly under the law.

As a liberal, health-conscious woman who’s lived her whole life in this country, I see policing as a public safety service that should protect everyone equally, not a source of fear—especially for communities of color. We need stricter national standards on use of force, mandatory body cameras, and real accountability when officers abuse their power, paired with strong bias training and better screening before people are even hired. At the same time, I’d like to see more investment in mental health professionals, social workers, and community programs so police aren’t the default responders to every problem. That combination—firm oversight plus smarter, community-centered support—is how we can reduce bias and violence without sacrificing safety.

As someone who spent her career working to protect both the environment and public health, I believe policing should be guided by evidence-based practices that reduce harm and build trust, especially in communities that have historically borne the brunt of bias and excessive force. We need strong accountability measures, rigorous de-escalation and anti-bias training, transparent data on stops and use of force, and a greater investment in social services and community-based programs so that police are not the default response to every problem. At the same time, I support well-trained officers who see themselves as partners with the community, not occupiers, and who are given the tools and oversight necessary to keep everyone safe—civilians and officers alike.

As someone who values order, family, and tradition, I believe police must be respected and supported so they can keep our communities safe, but they also must be held to clear, consistent standards that prevent unfair treatment and excessive force. Strong training in de-escalation, cultural and religious understanding, and strict accountability for misconduct can reduce bias without weakening law enforcement. When the rules are clear and applied equally, both officers and the public—especially immigrants and minorities—can feel safer and more secure.

As someone who’s seen how working-class and immigrant communities can be treated with suspicion, I think policing needs strong accountability measures—like body cameras, clear use-of-force standards, and independent oversight—to reduce bias and unnecessary violence. At the same time, we should invest more in community-based programs, mental health support, and de-escalation training so police aren’t the default answer to every problem and can focus on serious threats to public safety.

As a pharmacist and a mom, I see every day how much trust matters when people are vulnerable, and I think policing should be guided by that same principle. We need evidence-based reforms like de-escalation training, strict accountability for excessive force, body cameras, and transparent data on stops and arrests, especially to confront racial bias. At the same time, real public safety means investing in mental health services, community health, and social supports so that police aren’t the default response to every crisis, and officers can focus on the situations where they’re genuinely needed.

As a Korean American small business owner and a Jewish progressive Democrat, I want policing that truly protects everyone in my community, not just some of us. We need stronger bias training, independent oversight of use-of-force incidents, and clearer rules that prioritize de-escalation and mental health support so officers aren’t defaulting to violence. At the same time, my shop and my neighbors still rely on responsive, well-trained police who build trust by walking the streets, knowing local businesses, and treating every person with dignity. Real safety comes from both fair, accountable policing and investments in community services that prevent crime before it happens.

Como alguien que trabaja duro al aire libre y que ha tenido trato con la policía sobre todo por temas de trabajo y comunidad, yo pienso que la policía debe respetar a todos por igual, sin importar raza, papeles o acento. Necesitamos más entrenamiento en cómo calmar situaciones, menos mano dura innecesaria, y más oficiales que conozcan de verdad a los barrios donde trabajan. Al mismo tiempo, también es importante que haya ley y orden para que nuestras familias estén seguras, pero con cámaras corporales, reglas claras y consecuencias reales cuando un oficial abusa de su poder. Solo así se puede mantener la seguridad sin perder el respeto y la confianza de la gente.

As someone who cares about both community safety and fairness, I think policing needs to prioritize de-escalation training, strict accountability for misconduct, and transparent data on stops and use of force, especially in communities of color. I support reallocating some resources toward mental health responders and community services so officers aren’t asked to handle every social problem with a badge and a gun. At the same time, I believe well-trained, bias-aware police who build real relationships with neighborhoods can keep us safe without resorting to excessive force.

I think police should be trained a lot more on how to spot their own biases and de-escalate situations so they don’t jump to using force, especially against people who are already treated unfairly. There should be clear rules, body cameras, and real consequences if officers break those rules, but also enough support and resources so they can keep communities safe without feeling like violence is their first option.

As a mother and someone who works in healthcare, I want policing that treats everyone with the same care and respect we owe our patients—no exceptions. We need mandatory de-escalation and bias training, independent investigations of use-of-force incidents, and stronger community oversight so officers are accountable and trusted. At the same time, we should invest in mental health responders and community programs that prevent crime in the first place, so police aren’t asked to solve every social problem with a badge and a gun. That balance—firm accountability paired with smart prevention—is how we keep both our neighborhoods and our civil rights safe.

As a Christian, a mom, and someone deeply involved in community work, I believe policing must be rooted in dignity, accountability, and a genuine commitment to protecting all people equally. We need strong bias training, transparent use-of-force policies, and independent oversight so that officers who misuse power are held accountable, while also ensuring police have the support, training, and community partnerships they need to respond safely and effectively.

I want cops held to high standards and fully accountable when they abuse their power, but I don’t want to see public safety sacrificed or officers afraid to do their jobs. We should focus on better training in de-escalation, strict transparency on use-of-force incidents, and getting rid of bad officers quickly, instead of burying everyone in more regulations that don’t fix the real problems. At the same time, communities need to take some responsibility too—support the good cops, cooperate when there’s real crime, and push for policies based on data, not just politics or headlines.

As someone who believes in both safe communities and fairness, I think policing needs strong accountability measures, including body cameras, transparent reporting, and independent review of use-of-force incidents, especially where bias may be involved. Officers should receive intensive, ongoing training in de-escalation, mental health response, and implicit bias, and departments should be required to build real relationships with the neighborhoods they serve through community policing. We can support good officers, reduce unnecessary violence, and tackle racial and other biases without compromising public safety—in fact, doing so will strengthen trust and make everyone safer.

As someone who believes in law and order but also knows what it feels like to be looked at differently as a Black woman, I think police need strong, consistent training that focuses on de-escalation, treating everyone with dignity, and rooting out any bias, whether conscious or not. At the same time, officers deserve clear rules, community support, and the tools they need to stay safe, because we rely on them when things go wrong. I’d like to see more officers truly embedded in the neighborhoods they serve, building relationships through churches, schools, and local events so that trust goes both ways and deadly force becomes a last resort.

As someone who’s worn a uniform and believes strongly in individual liberty, I think policing has to be rooted in strict accountability and transparency, not blind loyalty to the badge. We should use body cameras, independent civilian review boards, and rigorous de-escalation training to reduce bias and excessive force, while still making sure officers have the tools and backing to confront real threats. Policies should be laser-focused on protecting constitutional rights, not padding arrest stats, and bad actors in any department should be removed quickly so the public can trust the officers who are doing it right.

I support our police and believe most of them are good people doing a hard job, but I also think there needs to be better training and clear consequences when officers cross the line, especially in cases involving bias or excessive force. We should invest in things like body cameras, de-escalation training, and closer community relationships so officers know the neighborhoods they serve and are held accountable. That way, we can keep our communities safe without people feeling unfairly targeted or afraid of the very folks meant to protect them.

As someone who cares deeply about social justice and works with kids every day, I think policing strategies must start with de-escalation, rigorous anti-bias training, and real accountability for misuse of force, especially in communities of color. We should invest more in mental health responders, community-based programs, and youth services so police aren’t the default answer to every problem. At the same time, clear, transparent standards for when force can be used—and body cameras with public reporting—can help maintain safety while rebuilding trust between officers and the communities they serve.
